data.value: As announced on 20 September 2021, archTIS acquired business technology assets, customers, and employees from Cipherpoint Limited and its subsidiaries.

Acquisition included intellectual property for ‘cp.Protect’ (an advanced SharePoint on-premises data encryption solution) and ‘cp.Discover’ (a data discovery and classification platform), along with new customer relationships (e.g., DHL, Bank of Finland, Arthur J. Gallagher) and key technology partners (NTT Singapore and NTT DATA Deutschland).
$1.4M initial cash consideration with an additional $0.1M settled on 31 March 2022.
Introduction of a new NC Protect watermarking feature to support CUI Designator labelling to meet US Defence, CMMC 2.0, NIST and ITAR compliance requirements.

CEO and Managing Director of archTIS. Extensive industry experience in delivering outcomes for government and commercial organisations, expertise in implementing organisational change and restructuring to address evolving business challenges.

Global COO & US President of archTIS. Brings over 25 years of technology leadership, experienced in scaling go to market strategies, previously served as CEO and General Manager in multiple technology companies with a track record of growth and successful exits.

Chief Financial Officer of archTIS with extensive SaaS industry experience. Held senior financial roles including TechnologyOne Director of Finance and Business Partnering, and previous roles in listed companies ensuring strong project management and change management.

Chief Technology Officer of archTIS. Responsible for managing technical strategy, service management, and key technology partnerships. Brings over 30 years of IT industry experience including significant federal government technology projects.

As Chief Engineer of archTIS, Leigh Rowland drives the evolution of the company’s technology, expanding NC Protect’s protection from on-premises SharePoint to cloud collaboration platforms such as SharePoint Online, Microsoft 365, Microsoft Teams, Nutanix, and Exchange emails. He began his career at Xerox and played key roles at startups including Cyxtera, Cryptzone (acquired by Cyxtera), and Create!form International. He holds a Bachelor of Science (Hons) in Mathematics from the University of York.

Irena Mroz is responsible for defining archTIS's branding, demand generation, and public relations. With more than 20 years of B2B marketing expertise, she leads the company's marketing strategy and communications programs. Her background includes senior marketing roles at cybersecurity startups and positions at companies such as Nucleus Cyber, Infocyte, Bottomline Technologies, and Create!form International. She holds a Bachelor of Science in Mass Communications from Boston University’s College of Communication.

data.key: BILL BELCHER - VICE PRESIDENT OF GLOBAL SALES
data.value: Bill Belcher brings over 30 years of experience building sales teams, reseller channels, and system integrator relationships. He is responsible for the company's global sales teams with a focus on expanding the use of archTIS NC Protect and Kojensi solutions across defense and civilian agencies. His career includes roles at Boldon James, GE, Micromuse, and Spirent Communications. He holds a BA in Economics and Political Science and a Master of Public Administration with a concentration in organizational development from The American University.

data.key: MATTHEW KLUKEN - VICE PRESIDENT & GENERAL MANAGER ASIA PACIFIC
data.value: Matt Kluken has 27 years of experience in the Information and Communication Technologies industry, having worked in sales, marketing, technical, and customer experience roles with companies such as Gartner, NetApp, CA Technologies, and Oracle. As VP & General Manager Asia Pacific, he focuses on building archTIS’s presence with global defense, intelligence, federal and state governments, and the defense industry, while expanding the partner ecosystem in the region.
Miles Jakeman, Daniel Lai, Leanne Graham

Specialist in business strategy, leadership, high performance team development, and risk management. Former CEO and technology business founder with extensive experience in guiding companies in global markets. Co-founded and served as Managing Director of The Citadel Group Limited, growing the company from a start-up to an ASX-listed entity with over 300 staff and a market capitalisation exceeding $400M, later sold for $503M.
Bachelor of Science (Hons), Graduate Diploma in Asian Studies, PhD in Asian Studies, and a second PhD in Business Leadership.

Fellow of the Australian Institute of Company Directors (AICD); completed AICD Diploma of International Company Directors and Mastering the Boardroom Advanced Diploma; appointed as a Member of the Order of Australia (AM).
1,634,545 ordinary shares and 1,360,000 unlisted options.

Details the key management personnel remuneration arrangements for the Group in accordance with section 300A of the Corporations Act 2001 and its Regulations.

Attract, motivate and retain high-performance and high-quality personnel, with remuneration for directors and executives not directly linked to Group performance. Annual fixed remuneration with incentive components based on agreed KPIs.
Consists of base pay and non-monetary benefits, short-term performance incentives, share-based payments, and other remuneration such as superannuation and long service leave.

Fees and payments reflect role responsibilities, are reviewed annually by the Board, and subject to ASX listing rules. Maximum annual aggregate remuneration approved by shareholders is $500,000 per annum.
Separate remuneration structures for non-executive and executive directors following best corporate governance practices.

elements.title: Directors’ Report Remuneration Report (AUDITED) - Executive Remuneration

data.value: Fixed remuneration, consisting of base salary, superannuation and non-monetary benefits, is reviewed annually based on individual, business unit, and Group performance as well as market comparisons. Executives may receive these in cash or non-cash forms such as motor vehicle benefits.
The STI program is designed to align business unit targets with executive performance hurdles, with payments granted based on achievement of specific annual targets and KPIs.

The LTI program includes long service leave and share-based payments, where securities are awarded over a three-year period and are based on measures such as increase in shareholders’ value relative to the market and competitors.

The remuneration report details the remuneration of key management personnel of the Group. The personnel include the Chairman, Managing Director & CEO, Non-executive Director, and Global Chief Operations Officer.

Table 'Directors and Key Management Personnel': Miles Jakeman AM (Chairman), Daniel Lai (Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer), Leanne Graham (Non-executive Director), Kurt Mueffelmann (Global Chief Operations Officer).

data.value: This table presents the share holdings for company personnel during the financial year. It lists data for Non-Executive Directors, Executive Directors, and Key Management Personnel. Key details include: Miles Jakeman AM held 1,634,545 shares throughout the period; Daniel Lai (Executive Director) had an opening balance of 9,574,252 shares, received an addition of 21,739 shares, and ended with 9,595,991 shares; Kurt Mueffelmann (Key Management Personnel) started with 17,772,859 shares, added 130,435 shares, and closed at 17,903,294 shares; Kylie Sheather maintained a zero balance. The summary notes that Kurt Mueffelmann holds the largest position.

This table details the movements in options and performance rights over ordinary shares for various personnel under the AR9012 Class. Highlights include: Miles Jakeman AM began with 360,000 units, was granted 1,000,000 and closed at 1,360,000; Leanne Graham (Non-Executive Director) was granted 750,000 with a minor adjustment (6,612 units expired/forfeited) to close at 756,612; Daniel Lai (Executive Director) received a grant of 612,245 with a forfeiture of 7,249 to finish with 619,491; Kurt Mueffelmann (Key Management Personnel) was granted 695,389 with 43,478 adjustments, closing at 783,867; Kylie Sheather (Key Management Personnel) was granted 522,794 with no forfeitures. Additionally, a note confirms that 612,245 Performance Rights were issued to Daniel Lai under the Company’s Employee Incentive Plan.

Under the long-term incentive plan, performance rights are granted to participants, entitling them to ordinary shares if specific financial performance hurdles (growth in revenue, annual recurring revenue, and containment of operating costs) are met, and provided the holder remains employed until vesting.
Performance rights for the 2022 financial year are subject to financial performance conditions, with challenging yet achievable metrics focused on sales growth and shareholder wealth creation.
The long-term incentive plan operates over a three-year period. Vesting occurs in two stages: 50% on 15 December 2022 and the balance on 15 June 2023, provided performance milestones are met.
The Incentive Performance Rights expire on 24 November 2023.

The grant date fair value is recognized as an employee benefits expense over the vesting period, with adjustments based on the actual number of performance rights meeting the service and performance conditions.

Depreciated on a straight-line basis over the unexpired lease term or the asset's estimated useful life, whichever is shorter. If ownership is expected at lease end, depreciation is over the estimated useful life.
The entity does not recognise right-of-use assets or lease liabilities for leases of 12 months or less and for low-value assets; lease payments are expensed as incurred.

Initial recognition at the present value of lease payments discounted using the interest rate implicit in the lease or the entity's incremental borrowing rate; subsequently measured at amortised cost with remeasurement adjustments.
Amortised systematically over the project’s useful life, matching the future economic benefits.

A 43.5% refundable tax offset on eligible R&D expenditure, recognised as government grants over the periods in which related expenses are incurred, with portions related to capitalised development deducted from related non-current assets.
Amortised on a straight-line basis over their finite life, typically between 3 to 5 years.
Deferred and amortised on a straight-line basis over an expected benefit period of 3 to 5 years.

Finite life intangible assets are measured at cost less amortisation and impairment; indefinite life intangibles are not amortised but are tested annually for impairment. Patents and trademarks are amortised over 10 years.

Goodwill is not amortised but tested annually for impairment. Other non-financial assets are reviewed for impairment when indications arise, with losses recognised when carrying amounts exceed recoverable amounts.

elements.title: NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 30 JUNE 2022

data.value: Note 12. Intangible assets

Product design and development expenses that create future benefits and meet certain criteria are capitalised as intangible assets, which are then amortised over the estimated useful life of the asset.
As part of the acquisition of the software division of Cipherpoint Limited on 20 September 2021, computer software and customer contracts were recognised.

Development costs qualify for capitalisation if technical feasibility is demonstrated, future economic benefits are probable, and costs can be reliably measured. Such assets are amortised on a straight-line basis over their useful life, for example, a software development asset with a useful life of five years.

Research phase expenditure is expensed as incurred, while development costs are capitalised only when future economic benefits can be reliably measured and technical feasibility is proven. Costs incurred post-launch or to enhance existing products are expensed, reflected under R&D expense.
The carrying value of intangibles is reviewed for impairment whenever events suggest that the asset's recoverability may be in doubt.

elements.title: Audit Report: Intangible Assets – Capitalisation and Impairment Assessment

data.value: Evaluation of the appropriateness of capitalisation policies as per AASB 138, including the decision to capitalise or expense costs.
Assessment of the annual asset life, impairment reviews, and the calculation of amortisation based on management’s judgements.
Examination of impairment assessments under AASB 136, including evaluation of expected future economic benefits attributable to intangible assets.
Procedures included testing samples of capitalised costs and reviewing relevant disclosures noted in Notes 1(q), 1(r), 2, and 12.

This table presents a cash flow statement comparing two periods. The company experienced a significant change in cash position, moving from a net decrease of $6.2M in the current period to a net increase of $10.3M in the previous period. Operating activities showed increased cash outflow, while financing activities generated substantial inflows primarily through the issuance of shares. Investing activities shifted from an outflow to an inflow between the periods.

elements.title: NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 30 JUNE 2022

data.value: Year Ended 30 June 2022
The financial statements have been prepared on a going concern basis, assuming continuity of normal business activities and realization of assets in the normal course.
Successful capital raising of $6.9 million completed on 23 December 2021
$6.5 million as at 30 June 2022, with an additional $2 million collected in July 2022
Prepared under Australian Accounting Standards and International Financial Reporting Standards using the historical cost convention, except for certain fair value recognitions.
The consolidated financial statements include all subsidiaries controlled by archTIS Limited; intercompany transactions and unrealised gains/losses are eliminated.
The financial statements are presented in Australian dollars (AUD)

elements.title: NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 30 JUNE 2022

data.value: Monetary assets and liabilities in foreign currencies are translated at financial year-end exchange rates. Foreign operations’ assets and liabilities are translated into Australian dollars using the reporting date rates, while revenues and expenses use average exchange rates. Resulting foreign exchange differences are recognized in other comprehensive income through the foreign currency reserve, which is reclassified to profit or loss upon disposal of the foreign operation or net investment.

Revenues from consulting services, sale of solution services, and software are recognized as performance obligations are satisfied. The process includes identifying the contract, performance obligations, determining the transaction price (including variable consideration like discounts, rebates, and potential bonuses), allocating the price to each obligation, and recognizing revenue over time or at a point in time as services are rendered.

Income tax expense or benefit is based on taxable income for the period adjusted by changes in deferred tax assets and liabilities resulting from temporary differences, unused tax losses, and prior period adjustments.

Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for temporary differences at enacted or substantively enacted rates. They are reviewed each reporting date and adjusted if future taxable profits are unlikely, with special treatment provided for items like goodwill and interests in subsidiaries or joint ventures. The tax consolidation for archTIS Limited and its wholly-owned Australian subsidiaries is also addressed.
Interest revenue is recognized as it accrues using the effective interest rate method, which calculates amortized cost and allocates interest income over the relevant period.

elements.title: NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 30 JUNE 2022

data.value: Discussion on the classification of current and non-current assets and liabilities, including criteria for current assets/liabilities, treatment of cash and cash equivalents (including bank overdrafts), derecognition of financial assets, impairment allowance for financial assets, and measurement of Property, Plant and Equipment, including depreciation (straight-line basis), derecognition, and treatment of revaluation surplus.

Table titled 'Lease Terms Schedule' showing leasehold improvements for office furniture & equipment and computer equipment with lease terms ranging from 2-4 years. The table summarizes lease terms applicable to items included in the property, plant and equipment or lease schedules.

Notes on review of residual values, useful lives and depreciation methods at each reporting date, derecognition of items upon disposal or when no future economic benefit exists, and details on recognition and measurement of right-of-use assets and other financial assets.

elements.title: NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS – SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES

data.value: Loans and borrowings are initially recognised at the fair value of the consideration received, net of transaction costs, and subsequently measured at amortised cost using the effective interest method.
Finance costs related to qualifying assets are capitalised, while all other finance costs are expensed as incurred.

Provisions are recognised when there is a present legal or constructive obligation from a past event, provided settlement is probable and can be reliably estimated. Discounting is applied if the time value of money is material.
Wages, salaries, and benefits expected to settle within 12 months are measured at expected settlement amounts.

Long-term benefits (annual and long service leave not settled within 12 months) are measured at the present value of expected future payments using the projected unit credit method, with future payments discounted at market yields.

Both equity-settled and cash-settled share-based transactions are measured at fair value using the Binomial option pricing model, with expenses recognised over the vesting period. Adjustments are made for modifications and market conditions.

data.value: $4,579,983 ($4,215,148 relating to tax losses) has not been recognised due to uncertainty in utilising temporary differences for taxable profit while claiming refundable R&D tax offset.

Significant increase in loss before income tax (from $(3,334,391) in 2021 to $(9,638,231) in 2022), decrease in total income tax expense/income (from $(342,989) to (192,943)), substantial increase in current year deferred tax not recognised (from $(47,795) to $1,532,311), and a marked decrease in Research & development expenditure (from $649,398 to $225,826).

elements.title: Notes to the Financial Statements - 30 June 2022

data.value: Table 'Cash and cash equivalents' shows that 'Cash at bank' decreased from 12,739,159 in 2021 to 6,520,536 in 2022 – approximately a 49% reduction in cash holdings.

The table presents data on expected credit losses and receivables. It reports an allowance for expected credit losses of 2,472,815 for the earlier period with other receivables detailed in two rows, suggesting a significant percentage increase (around 331%) in expected credit losses.

data.key: Aging Analysis of Carrying Amounts and Expected Credit Losses
data.value: The aging table for 2022 indicates that the majority of the carrying amount (2,017,358) is not yet due, with smaller amounts overdue in different time buckets. The total carrying amount is 2,472,815 with no allowances recorded across all periods.

The table for 'Other current assets' includes items such as Prepayments & deposits, Accrued income (newly recorded for 2022), Research & development tax incentive, and Capitalised commissions. Notably, R&D tax incentive increased from 1,434,753 in 2021 to 1,602,810 in 2022, and the overall total increased by roughly 16.9%.

elements.title: Note 12. Intangible assets (continued) - Intangible Assets and Goodwill Statement

data.value: 30 JUNE 2022

This table presents the movement of intangible assets and goodwill for the period ending June 30, 2022. The total net book value is $14,695,423. Notable changes include significant additions to development in progress and increased amortization across software assets. The company maintains a substantial goodwill balance of $2,789,524 with no impairment, while software represents the largest component at $6,117,155. Additionally, a deferred R&D tax incentive reduced the overall asset value by $3,583,058 at period end.

elements.title: NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 30 JUNE 2022 - Note 22. Reserves

data.value: The data indicates that the share-based payments reserve increased in 2022 relative to FY 2021, while the foreign currency component moved from a negative position in 2021 to a positive figure in 2022, resulting in an overall higher total reserve.

The tables also display historical movements of these reserves from July 2020 to June 2022, reflecting adjustments from share-based payment transactions and exchange differences from foreign operations translation.

elements.title: Notes to the Financial Statements - Retained Losses, Dividends, and Risk Management

data.value: Retained losses at the beginning of the financial year and loss after income tax expense for the year are detailed. For 2022, the losses were (13,699,219) and (9,445,288) respectively, compared to (10,707,817) and (2,991,402) in 2021. Retained losses at the end of the financial year increased from (13,699,219) in 2021 to (23,144,507) in 2022, signaling a deteriorating financial position.
No dividends were paid or declared during the year. Franking credits available based on a 26% tax rate remained constant at $15,549 for both 2021 and 2022.

The Group outlines its exposure to various financial risks including market risk, foreign exchange risk, price risk, interest rate risk, and credit risk. Risk management practices include sensitivity and ageing analyses and are carried out under policies approved by the Board.

elements.title: Notes to the Financial Statements – Operating Lease Commitments

data.value: Lease commitments - operating

The table discloses operating lease commitments for 2022. It is broken down into two periods: Within one year ($24,585) and One to five years ($30,731) with a Total of $55,316. No data is provided for 2021. These represent committed future lease obligations that are not yet recognised as liabilities.
Related commentary indicates that operating lease commitments include contracted amounts for office and computer equipment under non-cancellable leases expiring within one to five years.

elements.title: Notes to the Financial Statements – Related Party Transactions and Subsidiary Loans

data.value: Related Party Transactions and Subsidiary Loans

The table compares related party transactions and subsidiary loans for 2022 and 2021. Notable figures for 2022 include: Payment for Corporate Advisor services ($420,000), Loan to archTIS US, Inc. ($2,357,161), Loan to Nucleus Cyber Pty Ltd ($(88,115) indicating a negative adjustment), Loan to archTIS UK Limited ($422,482), and Loan to archTIS EU GmbH ($51,825) with a Total of $2,743,353. In 2021, the corresponding amounts were significantly lower, with a Total of $1,864,421.
All transactions were conducted on normal commercial terms at market rates.

elements.title: Notes to the Financial Statements for the Year Ended 30 June 2022

data.value: The preparation of the financial statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts.
The judgements, estimates and assumptions that have a significant risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities are discussed.
Equity-settled transactions measured by fair value of equity instruments at grant date using the Binomial model.
Tests for impairment of finite life and indefinite life intangible assets annually or more frequently if events indicate.
Evaluates conditions specific to non-financial assets other than goodwill and tests for impairment.
Significant judgement required in determining the provision for income tax based on anticipated tax audit issues.
Recognised for deductible temporary differences only if it is probable that future taxable amounts will be available.
Liabilities for employee benefits expected to be settled more than 12 months are recognised at present value.
Future restoration costs for leased premises are provisioned based on future cost estimates.
Consideration of impacts of the pandemic on the consolidated entity's operations.
Initial accounting for business combinations is provisional with fair value estimations.
